abstract: A picture caption on Monday with an article about a battle between Wells Fargo and Citigroup over the purchase of the Wachovia Corporation misspelled, in some editions, the surname of Wachovia’s chief executive, who was shown with lawyers outside a federal court. The article also misstated his middle initial in some editions. He is Robert K. Steel, not Robert S. Steele.
snippet: A picture caption on Monday with an article about a battle between Wells Fargo and Citigroup over the purchase of the Wachovia Corporation misspelled, in some editions, the surname of Wachovia’s chief executive, who was shown with lawyers outside ...
lead_paragraph: A picture caption on Monday with an article about a battle between Wells Fargo and Citigroup over the purchase of the Wachovia Corporation misspelled, in some editions, the surname of Wachovia’s chief executive, who was shown with lawyers outside a federal court. The article also misstated his middle initial in some editions. He is Robert K. Steel, not Robert S. Steele.

abstract: As Wells Fargo and Citigroup haggle over who will get to acquire Wachovia, many news reports are pointing out that Wells Fargo’s $15 billion offer for Wachovia doesn’t require government assistance. By contrast, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation is backstopping some of the potential losses in Citi’s $2 billion deal.
lead_paragraph: As Wells Fargo and Citigroup haggle over who will get to acquire Wachovia, many news reports are pointing out that Wells Fargo’s $15 billion offer for Wachovia doesn’t require government assistance. By contrast, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation is backstopping some of the potential losses in Citi’s $2 billion deal.

headline.main: Bank Deals Get Help From the I.R.S.
